I'm sorry--I think I consigned your message along with a lot of other 
messages with the subject line a couple days ago.  Good questions.

mherrmann_at wrote:

> I'm sorry for repeating myself but I fear that my last message
> (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/15268) 
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/15268%29> might have been
> overlooked.
>
> What do the people who haven't yet responded think about
> @Before/@BeforeClass vs. @BeforeTest/@BeforeSuite? Please, give us
> your comments. Nothing will happen if you don't speak your mind!

There's an interesting, whimsical point in favor of @Before that I'll 
bring up in a future post.

> What is the overall opinion about Joe Walnes' aproach to flexible
> JUnit assertions using assertThat? 

It's great.

> Do you think it is better or worse
> than the current assertions? 

I use both together.

> I would like to have it included in the
> new release, would you too? David, why do you think using constraints
> is heavy weight?

Constraint in JMock has two abstract methods: eval and describeTo.  
Describe is really cool, because it allows, basically for free, error 
messages like:

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
Expected: not (eq(<a bad sentence>) or a string containing "a bad word")
but got : This is a bad word

On the other hand, it can double the amount of work for each 
implementing class.  I'm still split on whether this is worth it.

This is actually a lot different than saying "Constraints are heavy 
weight".  It may be the same thing as saying "it's not yet quite clear 
what the perfect definition of assertThat is".

> And why
> 1) does junit.framework.Assert still define assertEquals for
> boolean, int, long etc. (autoboxing could do that; in fact, deleting
> those methods doesn't produce any errors)?

> 2) isn't java.lang.AssertionError used instead of
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError?

junit.framework.Assert is there for backward compatibility.  For 
org.junit.Assert, #2 is already true, and #1 is interesting...

    David Saff
